<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->Note to reviewers: This pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* #13054 (tests: Enable automatic detection of undefined names in Python tests scripts. Remove wildcard imports. by practicalswift)
* #12360 (Bury bip9 deployments by jnewbery)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Id
Concept ACK, but let's try not to overshoot the target by pleasing some obscure style rules that contradict our style guide.
> Concept ACK, but let's try not to overshoot the target by pleasing some obscure style rules that contradict our style guide.\n\nSorry - will address your comments. Was travelling last week.
Comments addressed. Thanks for the review @MarcoFalke !
rebased

Thanks @conscott !

> what do you think about moving these functions back to mininode.py?

Seems reasonable if they can be used by multiple tests, although blocktools.py might be a better place for them.
utACK e3aab295e7c91d08bd577f9fb05f6bb8e585870a
Thanks for the review @MarcoFalke - I'll try to address your comments in a follow-up PR.
Imo we indicate "compile time" constants with upper case, so I'd prefer if they were left that way, since it makes it easier to read.
Those are message types and not from mininode. I'd prefer to keep it the way it was over changing it in the wrong way.
C.f. https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/doc/developer-notes.md#coding-style\n\n> Constant names are all uppercase, and use _ to separate words.

Thanks for pointing this out. These were previously being imported indirectly through the `from mininode import *` import, but you're right that I should fix that to import from messages.py in this commit.\n\nI've now put them in the right place.
That's not fair! Those are C++ style guides.\n\nBut fine, reverted to all caps.
in commit f7c7f8ecf3 [tests] p2p_segwit: Fix flake8 warnings\n\nYou change a constant to lowercase. Imo this makes the code harder to read, as mentioned in my previous review.
same here
